justification: Participants completed “the English version of the LexTALE” and their scores were used as one of “the two language-proficiency measures” to select and describe the sample.
Eligibility and analysis relied on scores from “the Dutch version of the LexTALE,” treated as the complementary native-language proficiency measure for bilinguals.

The study states that “participants see pairs of words and are asked to decide…whether the words in each pair are related,” noting that this task “requires access to the semantic representation” and was the main tool for examining semantic processing.

Throughout the introduction the authors note that the cognate facilitation effect and interlingual homograph inhibition effect have been “most commonly observed in visual lexical decision experiments,” indicating this task is the standard measure for lexical access phenomena.
construct: Lexical access / cognate facilitation and interlingual homograph inhibition
